articles.headline: President Plans Own Panel on the Debt
articles.snippet: A plan for a bipartisan commission to press for tax increases and spending cuts failed in the Senate, but President Obama may establish a similar panel by executive order.
articles.abstract: A plan for a bipartisan commission to press for tax increases and spending cuts failed in the Senate, but President Obama may establish a similar panel by executive order.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Advocates of more aggressive steps to address the national debt failed Tuesday in their effort to create a bipartisan commission to press for tax increases and spending cuts, but President Obama now plans to establish a similar panel by executive order in his State of the Union address on Wednesday.

articles.headline: British Central Banker Favors Splitting Big Banks
articles.snippet: An argument once seen as an academic debate is now gaining traction among policy makers.
articles.abstract: An argument once seen as an academic debate is now gaining traction among policy makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Mervyn A. King, the governor of the Bank of England, is an owlish, self-effacing man who, in contrast to his more outspoken peers in Frankfurt and Washington, strikes a public posture that borders on the demure.

articles.headline: Toyota Halts Sales of 8 Models in U.S. for Pedal Flaw
articles.snippet: Toyota Motor Company will temporarily stop selling and building eight models for the U.S. market while it tries to resolve a problem with accelerator pedals.
articles.abstract: Toyota Motor Company will temporarily stop selling and building eight models for the U.S. market while it tries to resolve a problem with accelerator pedals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Toyota Motor, still struggling to resolve a problem with accelerator pedals, said Tuesday that it would temporarily stop building and selling eight models, including the popular Camry and Corolla sedans, in the North American market.

articles.headline: G.M. Enters Agreement to Sell Saab to Spyker
articles.snippet: Under the deal, Spyker will give G.M. $74 million in cash and $326 million in preferred shares of the combined Spyker-Saab entity.
articles.abstract: Under the deal, Spyker will give G.M. $74 million in cash and $326 million in preferred shares of the combined Spyker-Saab entity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saab, the Swedish automaker that seemed destined for the junkyard a month ago after its owner, General Motors, said it could not find a buyer, won a new lease on life Tuesday when G.M. agreed to sell Saab to a tiny Dutch maker of high-end sports cars.

articles.headline: Courts as Battlefields in Climate Fights
articles.snippet: Lawsuits against energy companies, like one brought by an island village in Alaska, are picking up steam.
articles.abstract: Lawsuits against energy companies, like one brought by an island village in Alaska, are picking up steam.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tiny Kivalina, Alaska, does not have a hotel, a restaurant or a movie theater. But it has a very big lawsuit that might affect the way the nation deals with climate change.

articles.headline: With Sun, Oracle Aims at Giants
articles.snippet: The $7.4 billion deal to acquire Sun Microsystems, which gives Oracle a vast hardware business for the first time, pits it against Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M., Dell and Cisco Systems.
articles.abstract: The $7.4 billion deal to acquire Sun Microsystems, which gives Oracle a vast hardware business for the first time, pits it against Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M., Dell and Cisco Systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Oracle, having spent the last nine months fighting rivals and regulators in order to own Sun Microsystems, has pushed itself into the middle of the scrum of technology heavyweights all jostling for the same corporate customers.

articles.headline: Two at Fed Had Doubts Over Payout by A.I.G.
articles.snippet: After rescuing the American International Group with a loan, federal officials rejected forcing trading partners to return $30 billion they had received from A.I.G.
articles.abstract: After rescuing the American International Group with a loan, federal officials rejected forcing trading partners to return $30 billion they had received from A.I.G.
articles.lead_paragraph: Weeks after rescuing the American International Group with an $85 billion taxpayer loan in late 2008, Federal Reserve Board officials rejected a proposal that would have forced the insurer’s trading partners to return $30 billion in cash that they had received from A.I.G. in the preceding months.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story

articles.headline: Haiti’s Children Adrift in World of Chaos
articles.snippet: Children, 45 percent of Haiti’s population, are among the most disoriented and vulnerable quake survivors.
articles.abstract: Children, 45 percent of Haiti’s population, are among the most disoriented and vulnerable quake survivors.
articles.lead_paragraph: CROIX DES BOUQUETS, Haiti  Not long after 14-year-old Daphne Joseph escaped her collapsed house on the day of the earthquake, she boarded a crowded jitney with her uncle and crawled in traffic toward the capital, where her single mother sold beauty products in the Tête Boeuf marketplace. “Mama,” she said she repeated to herself. “Mama, I’m coming.”

articles.headline: Ailing Banks Favor Salaries Over Shareholders
articles.snippet: A few struggling banks in the postbailout world are by some measures the industry’s most generous employers.
articles.abstract: A few struggling banks in the postbailout world are by some measures the industry’s most generous employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finding the winners on Wall Street is usually as simple as looking at pay. Rarely are bankers who lose money paid as generously as those who make it.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Hunt for Ways to Rekindle Hiring
articles.snippet: Washington has been looking for ways to promote job growth while balancing economic policy and concerns about the deficit.
articles.abstract: Washington has been looking for ways to promote job growth while balancing economic policy and concerns about the deficit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Legislators are showing renewed interest in proposals for a government subsidy to encourage new hiring. President Obama last month endorsed the idea of a tax incentive for companies that add jobs, and many will be listening for more details in his State of the Union speech Wednesday night.

articles.headline: As Technology Surges, Radiation Safeguards Lag
articles.snippet: While new treatments are more accurate, errors in software and operation are more difficult to detect.
articles.abstract: While new treatments are more accurate, errors in software and operation are more difficult to detect.
articles.lead_paragraph: In New Jersey, 36 cancer patients at a veterans hospital in East Orange were overradiated  and 20 more received substandard treatment  by a medical team that lacked experience in using a machine that generated high-powered beams of radiation. The mistakes, which have not been publicly reported, continued for months because the hospital had no system in place to catch the errors.
